Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:604Y-FV81-DXH2-64K0-00000-00U.S. Fed Sparks Global Rally; President Trump Expected to Sign Executive Order on Police Reform Today; Trump Slams Seattle Leaders Over Autonomous Zone; Fed & White House taking action; Fed sparks late-day rally; U.S. Fed sparks global rally; Bezos on The Hill; No mask, no Fly: United requiring all passengers to wear ask on flights; Infrastructure to boost economy; Fed's Covid programs; America's up and coming careers; So long, standardized testing; radiology job opportunities; Treatment and prevention: Radiology jobs in demand amid Covid-19 pandemic; No Test required: Harvard won't require SAT, ACT for admissions next year; Tampa Bay teasing Brady's new look.2020-06-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:50ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTNancy Lazar, Robert Day, Cabot Philips, Jon Hilsenrath, Mick Mulvaney, Nury TurkelNEWSFinancial061602cb.231U.S. Fed Sparks Global Rally; President Trump Expected to Sign Executive Order on Police Reform Today; Trump Slams Seattle Leaders Over Autonomous Zone; Fed & White House taking action; Fed sparks late-day rally; U.S. Fed sparks global rally; Bezos on The Hill; No mask, no Fly: United requiring all passengers to wear ask on flights; Infrastructure to boost economy; Fed's Covid programs; America's up and coming careers; So long, standardized testing; radiology job opportunities; Treatment and prevention: Radiology jobs in demand amid Covid-19 pandemic; No Test required: Harvard won't require SAT, ACT for admissions next year; Tampa Bay teasing Brady's new look.Maria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Dagen McDowell, Jeff Flock

MARIA BARTIROMO, ANCHOR, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Welcome back to Tuesday morning everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, June 16th, your top stories right now. It is 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast. Boosting the U.S. economy, the Federal Reserve will be buying individual corporate bonds, and the White House reportedly is working on a $1 trillion infrastructure package.

The news helping fuel markets across the world this morning. Take a look at futures indicating a big triple-digit move at the start of trading this morning, up almost 500 points on the Dow Industrials this morning. The Dow up 473, that is almost 2 percent, the Nasdaq is up 119 points, one and a quarter percent, and the S&P 500 right now up 39 points, better than 1 percent there as well.

This on top of a big late day comeback yesterday, following news from the Federal Reserve, the Dow Industrials going from negative to up 157 points at the close. The Nasdaq was up 137 points, and then the S&P 500 up 25 at 4 O'clock on Wall Street yesterday. Police reform on the agenda, President Trump calling for change. He is expected to sign an executive order later today, overhauling policing in America.

Coming up at 8:00 a.m. Eastern this morning, former senior adviser to President Obama, Valerie Jarrett will join me, don't miss her take on police reforms and the 2020 race as presumptive Democratic candidate Joe Biden narrows in on his pick for vice president. Concerns over coronavirus is spiking, cases in the United States now surpassing 2.1 million with more than 116,000 people dead from coronavirus.

The death toll is expected to top 200,000 by October. This morning at 8:30 a.m. Eastern, we get another look at the impact the virus is having on the economy when we get the May retail sales numbers released. We are expecting better numbers this morning. We will get those numbers as soon as they hit the tape and show you the impact on markets.

Growing tensions meanwhile between North and South Korea. North Korea reportedly blowing up an inter-Korean liaison office building near the border. Plus, the next jobs in America, demand for radiology technicians surging, find out what it takes to get into this expanding area of healthcare. MORNINGS WITH MARIA is live right now.

Stimulus from the Federal Reserve sparking a global rally, in Europe, it is green across the board this morning. Take a look at the FTSE 100 up 161 points, two and two-thirds percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up 127, that's two and two-thirds percent, and the Dax index in Germany up better than 3 percent for the gain of 386 points right now. Similar story overnight in Asia where markets soared, the Bank of Japan, part of that, taking action, again increasing lending to cash-strapped businesses.

The BOG goes from $700 billion to $1 trillion in stimulus. All right, coming up this morning and joining the conversation, Dagen McDowell, Jon Hilsenrath and Cabot Phillips, great to see everybody this morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS: Great to see you.

CABOT PHILLIPS, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, CAMPUSREFORM.ORG: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: First though, some of the top stories we're watching right now, President Trump is expected to sign an executive order on police reform today as calls for change grow nationwide. It will promote a community- based policing strategy focused on officer behavior, use of force and information-sharing about bad cops in an effort to rebuild trust.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have mostly great people. I know so many of them, law enforcement. But we will do better, even better, and we're going to try and do it fast. But this is about law and order, but it's about justice also and it's about safety.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The executive order includes creating credentialing and certification incentives, improving officer retention and recruitment, and also prioritizing correspondent services. House Democrats start marking up their justice in policing act today with a floor vote expected on Thursday. Senator Tim Scott who has led the effort on the GOP's plan is expected to unveil the Republican proposal this week as well.

The NYPD says there was no criminality by Shake Shack employees after three officers got sick drinking milkshakes. The detectives now looking into whether the officers were accidentally sickened by an improperly cleaned machine. The president of the New York City Police Union says the officers were working protest detail when they discovered a toxic substance believed to be bleach in their beverages.

The officers are expected to recover. Shake Shack tweeted this, this morning. "Our team is working hard to get the full picture. In the meantime, we're relieved to hear the officers are all OK." From Shake Shack. Meanwhile, President Trump is slamming Seattle leaders for failing to break up an occupied zone.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: These people have taken over a vast part of -- a major part of a very good part of a place called Seattle. Seattle is big stuff. That's a major city. We have a governor that doesn't do a damn thing about it, and you have a mayor that doesn't know she's alive.

If they don't do the job, I'll do the job. And I've already spoken to the Attorney General about it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The occupation of chop, that is the Capitol Hill organized protest, is in its second week. Seattle's police chief says that despite claims the area is cop-free, officers will respond if there's a threat to safety. A landmark decision for LGBT workers, the Supreme Court ruling a key part of the 1964 civil rights act protects gay and transgender workers from discrimination in the workplace.

Two conservative Justices Neil Gorsuch and Chief Justice John Roberts joining liberals on the high court on the ruling, which comes five years after the Supreme Court legalized same-sex marriage. And Apple is facing new scrutiny this morning by the European Union. Anti-trust regulators have opened two investigations into the company's Apple Pay service and its App Store.

At issue is whether the company violated competition laws. Apple could be fined up to 10 percent of its annual revenue and forced to make changes to how it does business. The company says it's disappointed with the EU's inquiries. Taking a look at the stock this morning in the pre-market, it is still up, better than 1 percent at $347 a share. Markets poised for a rebound this morning, gains prompted by reports that the Trump administration is planning a $1 trillion infrastructure plan to stimulate the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic.

This plan is being prepared by the Department of Transportation. The president is expected to discuss it on Thursday. Joining me right now is former White House acting Chief of Staff, former OMB Director Mick Mulvaney. And Mick, it's great to have you this morning, thanks so much for joining me.

MICK MULVANEY, FORMER ACTING WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: Maria, it's been too long, it's good to be back, thank you.

BARTIROMO: How accurate in your view, pardon me, is a stimulus plan, this next stimulus plan, focused on infrastructure, or are there other things in the way of relief that you believe are needed right now?

MULVANEY: Yes, I think a couple of different things about that. First of all, infrastructure is a really difficult tool to use as stimulus because it simply takes too long to get the money into the system. I've had this conversations with folks in the administration, and it could take years for money to get for things like roads and bridges and so forth.

We learned that during the Obama administration. Infrastructure sounds great, but it's really a very poor sort of short-term stimulative tool. If we're going to look at a larger package, we're going to look at a package, and my guess is Congress will, that's just what Congress does. I hope we look at it through the eyes of the economic need and not sort of the political expediency. I hope it's -- if Steven Mnuchin and Kevin Hassett go to the president of the United States and say we need these economic policies, these economic stimuli, that's a good reason to move forward.

If the political advisors come in and say we need to do this in order to help us with the election. You can't buy elections. We should be looking at this through a very sort of disciplined economic approach, and if we need more economic stimulus, then let's get it. I'm not convinced we do yet just because so much of the money that we've already appropriated already passed a previous legislation, has not entered the system yet. And I don't want to see us act too quickly and over-stimulate the economy.

BARTIROMO: And so where are the needs, though, right now then, Mick? I mean, when you look at where you're seeing the most trouble, I mean, you've got certain industries like hotels and restaurants needing stimulus badly. They are living on cash flow and there's none of it during the shutdown. You also have community banks, this is where main street America banks, the community banks.

They're talking about needing stimulus. So in your view right now, knowing of all of the trillions that have already been thrown at this economy, where are the needs today?

MULVANEY: Thank you. But a lot of those trillions that have been thrown haven't hit the economy yet. But to your point, I think it's real difficult for the government to pick winners and losers when it comes to industries, to say we're going to help hotels but not cruise lines or airlines, but not Boeing. That's really difficult to do and it would open anybody up to sort of second-guessing after the fact, again, lessons that were learned after the financial crisis of the last decade.

I think it's better to look at sort of the larger market drivers, is capital available, to your point? Are community banks able to lend money to small businesses? Are the capital markets functioning properly? Are payrolls flowing? I think those are the type of things you should look at as opposed to saying, yes, to this industry and no to that industry.

So, any good stimulus package, I think is going to look at the big picture, and not try and pick winners or losers.

BARTIROMO: Well, in terms of winners or losers, we've already seen certain money going to certain industries, the airlines obviously --

MULVANEY: Yes --

BARTIROMO: Getting a big help from government where there were stakes taken. Payroll tax holiday is something your colleague, former colleague, Larry Kudlow talked about on Sunday. Here's what he said about the next relief package. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What are the must-haves in the next stimulus package to keep this economy going and growing?

LARRY KUDLOW, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL, UNITED STATES: The president has talked about a payroll tax holiday for the workforce. That will provide a terrific incentive for them to go back to work. I think it's a great idea. He's talked about capital gains. He has indeed talked about as my colleague, Navarro has said, let's try to help bring American companies back home from China which has been an unreliable place. We can use tax incentives and other ways and means to help them come home.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Do you believe those things will be in the next released package, bringing supply chains incentives to get companies to bring their supply chains back to America or out of China --

MULVANEY: Yes, those are --

BARTIROMO: At a minimum?

MULVANEY: Yes, those are the types of sort of general policies that I was talking about a second ago that I think actually could be helpful. You're not targeting this industry or that or this business or that, you're sort of trying to change the environment that we're in. On a middle class -- on a payroll tax cut, yes, it's a good way to get money to the middle class in a quick fashion which is good.

That being said, it does sort of undermine the long-term viability of the various trust funds, social security and Medicare. So we have to be careful with that. But you talk about what must -- what has to be in a must pass. I hope that we also sit back and realize that -- and I know I'm going to sound ideological, but it's important to think about this for a second. We are going to grow government in leaps and bounds.

In fact, we already have. I hope that if we look at a stimulus package going forward, another bill that we find ways to make sure that we can shrink the government back down to a normal size when this need has passed. My fear is that all we're doing is --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

MULVANEY: Raising the base, and that there's never going to be -- we do the same thing we did back in 2008, 2009, which is we grew the government and the government never got any smaller after that. So are there things in the stimulus to allow us to shrink the government, control growth, control spending. Will there be a way for example to have civil service reform to allow any president of the United States to fire underperforming federal workers. Things like that --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

MULVANEY: Should be included in the --

BARTIROMO: That's a good point, yes --

MULVANEY: Stimulus package.

BARTIROMO: So that was my next question, when did the chickens come home to roost? I mean, you're talking about $10 trillion in stimulus. Now, we look at the economy and the debt, almost the same size, $22 trillion in debt, rivaling the size of the entire economy. What's the solution? Will taxes have to go up in the coming years, Mick? I mean, is that a certainty?

MULVANEY: Well, I think as soon as the Democrats have the ability to pass legislation, taxes are going to go up. They're very straightforward about that. This goes back to the classic sort of debate that you and I have talked about before, which is, look, I love to think that we could cut our way to spend, to reduce spending in this country.

We've just not been able to do it. The center of gravity in Congress is always to spend more money. And until we change that, there's only two pieces left, which is either you have to raise revenues, which means raising taxes or you grow the government -- excuse me, you grow the economy which is what I think we were doing with such great success before the COVID crisis.

We were proving that supply side economics works. I think one of the great stories of this administration, 10, 20 years from now will be to look back from an economics standpoint and realize a supply side economics work. We were able to have really sustained growth, really low unemployment rates with really low inflation.

And demand-siders will tell you can't do that. But we prove that supply side economics works. So I hope that we get a chance to continue that experiment as we come out the backside of this COVID crisis.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll be watching, Mick Mulvaney, good to see you this morning, sir, thanks so much.

MULVANEY: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: We will see you soon. We still got a lot ahead. Coming up next hour, don't miss my first on Fox Business interview with former senior adviser to President Obama and the author of "Finding My Voice", Valerie Jarrett is here. I'll ask her about her stance on President Trump's executive order on police reform. The shortlist for presumptive Democratic candidate Joe Biden's vice president and a lot more. That's coming up right here, stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. New concerns this morning from the trucking industry. Many drivers are anxious about traveling through areas that could see disbanded police departments. Jeff Flock is live this morning in Lake Station, Indiana with a new take from truckers. Jeff.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: From the website Cdllife.com, Maria, that stands of course for commercial driver's license, CDL life did a poll of its truckers and asked the question, would you deliver or pick up in cities that had disbanded or defunded police departments? Of the 1,200 or so respondents, 79 percent said that they would not do so. Among the comments from the truckers, one saying I have already informed my dispatcher that I will refuse all loads to cities that have defunded police departments.

And others saying this is not an area you need to act fearless and think you'd look like a fool for saying no. Yet another, if something was to happen and you have to take matters into your own hands, then you could be prosecuted for protecting yourself. I point out to you, Maria, that according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, trucking is the -- at least, it was in 2018 the most deadly profession followed by construction workers, farmers, ranchers and maintenance workers.

I will point out that on that cdllife.com website, one African-American trucker wrote this, and I'll quote him. He said "we say black lives matter, not only black lives matter. We know that all lives matter, we just need your help with black lives matter right now because black lives are in danger." All viewpoints made clear. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Jeff, thank you. Jeff Flock this morning. In Indiana, we'll take a short break. More MORNINGS WITH MARIA when we come right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Lawmakers in Washington sending a clear signal to Beijing, they will not stand by in the face of China's human rights abuses. Congress overwhelmingly passing the Uyghur Human Rights Policy Act, sanctioning Chinese officials for forcibly detaining up to 2 million ethnic Muslims in internment camps.

Some are pushing the Trump administration to go even further. Joining me right now is Attorney, Co-founder and Board Chairman of the Uyghur Human Rights Project, Nury Turkel. Nury, it's good to have you this morning, thanks very much for joining us. And we should point out your parents were among those in Uyghur camps at one point or your -- some in your family. Explain the connection.

NURY TURKEL, ATTORNEY & CO-FOUNDER, UYGHUR HUMAN RIGHTS PROJECT: Thank you very much, Maria, good to be with you. Actually, I was born in the re- education camp at the height of the cultural revolution. But the Uyghur suffering has been going on as long as I have been breathing. To the Chinese government, the Uyghur people are different, being different is unacceptable.

Therefore, the Uyghur people has to go through what they call as the transformation process, which is one of the key objectives of the Chinese government towards the Uyghur people, to go through this human engineering that we're seeing in 2020.

BARTIROMO: So explain what has taken place, Nury. I mean, you say that the U.S. should sanction Chinese officials and Congress should pass a second bill for anyone involved in this. In other words, there are individuals who want to study their own religion, whether it be Muslim, Tibetan, whatever, that's not allowed in China. So, they put people -- lock these people up in camps and force them to study Chinese culture. What else are they doing to those people, Nury?

TURKEL: The U.S. ambassador for International Religious Freedom Sam Brownback said it best that the Chinese Communist Party is on a war -- unsafe. So any western religion, Islamic, Christianity, to the Chinese government have been perceived as a sign of disloyalty. So, as long as you practice religion, as long as you believe in something that is not in line with Xi Jinping's thoughts in these days, that there's a thing called Xi Jinping thoughts.

And also as long as you maintain your religious and ethnic background practices, way of life, like the Tibetans and Uyghurs, the Chinese government see you as a potential threat. In the last three years, the Chinese government through a "legislative process", quote, unquote, much like the one that they put in place for Hong Kong, legitimized its operation, criminalizing over 40 behaviors that are acceptable, cherished and protected in civilized society, such as growing beard, wearing head scarves, adhering to a certain diet and encouraging that children to stay in their marriage within the ethnic group.

So that kind of basic forms of social behavior, cultural appreciation has been criminalized by the Communist Party and Xi Jinping's China.

BARTIROMO: I mean, we heard stories of you know, for example, during Ramadan, officers going over there and forcing them to eat pork. I'm talking about serious human rights abuses, slave labor. Are you seeing any of that at these camps? Explain what goes on at those camps, Nury, because there are some people out there who refer to them as concentration camps which is obviously an incredibly aggressive way to, you know, name these camps. How do you see it?

TURKEL: Three things are happening in Xi Jinping's China. One, since late 2016 under the leadership of Chen Quanguo who used to be the head of the Communist Party in Tibet, the Chinese government turned an area that is known as East Turkestan to the Uyghurs and known as Xinjiang by the Chinese government into an open air prison-like environment.

They built a pervasive surveillance apparatus, monitoring every aspect of Uyghur lives and also engaging in mass detention of the Uyghurs into the modern day concentration camps. Those concentration camps that the Chinese government built share a lot of commonality with the ones that we have seen them in history. And then third, the Chinese government through his re- education camp process, concentration camp, and now the labor camps, polluted the global supply chain.

So if you're buying anything made in China, cotton products, there's a chance -- there's a high likelihood that they have been made in the forced labor camps. As being recorded --

BARTIROMO: Wow --

TURKEL: Over 80 percent of the cotton products made in China are sourced in the Uyghur region. One quarter of the world's supply chain made in that part of the world made up of cotton --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

TURKEL: Likely or possibly been produced by forced labor. So slavery is back. Whenever the cotton is being mentioned, the American people can relate to that history. So, it is disturbing --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

TURKEL: That the Chinese government is using the Uyghurs, particularly since COVID, they transferred a large number of Uyghurs based on the "China Morning Post", and also "Radio for Asia", and large numbers of Uyghurs have been transferred into the coastal assembly lines to work and fill up the labor shortage.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my goodness, really tough stories. Real quick, before you go, Nury, you said at the top of this interview you were born in the middle of this. How did you get out?

TURKEL: I was -- my mother was six months pregnant when she was detained for what they call the political history. So we spent -- I was born in the captivity. My mother was cast down because of the beating and abuses that she suffered. And we were released several months after I was born. So I suffered a very extensive medical condition. So, you know, that's the different type of camp that we have seen in history, it was mostly focused on ideology.

But the current camps that the Chinese government set up in the last three years has a racist purpose and a genocidal --

BARTIROMO: OK --

TURKEL: Intention.

BARTIROMO: Really hard stuff to take. I'm sorry that you had to endure all of that, Nury, and we will watch the progress here. President Trump expected to sign that into law, the Uyghur Bill. Nury Turkel, thanks very much for your insights this morning and for joining us with all of that. Nury Turkel joining us there.

Quick break and then the U.S. jobs market attempting to recover, we're taking a look at how and in terms of radiology, this is emerging as an up and coming industry for American jobs post-pandemic. We're going to tell you what training skills are needed. Then keeping big tech in check, Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos reportedly agreeing to testify on Capitol Hill amid anti-trust investigations into big technology companies. All the details right after this. Stay with us.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Welcome back to Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, June 16. Your top stories right now 7:32 AM on the East Coast.

Boosting the American economy, the Federal Reserve buy individual corporate bonds and the White House is reportedly working on a $1 trillion infrastructure package leading to a global rally this morning. Futures indicating a gain of 400 points right out of the gate.

The Dow futures are up 429, one and two-thirds percent. The Nasdaq is up 108, better than one percent, and the S&P 500 right now up 35 points, also 1.1 percent higher there. U.S. markets staged a late-day come back yesterday as well following news from the federal reserve, some people calling it a short squeeze as well.

The Dow industrials up yesterday 157 points. The Nasdaq was up a 137 and the S&P was up 25 at 4:00 on Wall Street yesterday. Stimulus from the U.S. federal reserve boosting markets overseas as well. European indices are higher across the board with the FT100 up a 156, the CAC quant up a 122 and the Dax index in Germany, up 363 right now.

In Asia overnight, similar story and the Bank of Japan comes into play here. The BOJ also taking action, increasing lending to cash strapped businesses. They went from 700 billion to $1 trillion in aid from the Bank of Japan.

Meanwhile, there's Jeff Bezos set to make his first appearance before Congress. Cheryl Casone with those details right now. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: It's going to be something Maria. Good morning again. Well, according to The New York Times, Amazon lawyers have told lawmakers Bezos will testify before the House Judiciary Committee as part of its anti-trust investigation into Big Tech companies.

Lawmakers are expected to ask Bezos to respond to claims that his company uses its power against small businesses that sell on its site. Those third party sellers and he will likely be asked about alleged mistreatment of warehouse workers during the Covid-19 pandemic.

That hearing which could include other Big Tech CEOs is expected to take place sometime this summer. Ahead of the opening bell shows the Amazon were up more than one percent right now.

Well, United Airlines rolling out a strict new facemask policy, starting this Thursday. If you're not wearing a mask, you're going to be denied boarding and placed on an internal travel restriction list. Mask will be given to passengers if they don't have one and passengers will also have to complete a health self-assessment form.

Airlines have been requiring customers to wear masks on board since May and most passengers, they say have complied. Stock up about 8 percent right now. United like other major airlines trying to recover from the pandemic's effect on air travel.

30 percent of United flights likely are going to be in the air, next month. Just 30 percent. Finally, here's a look at what is trending this morning on FoxBusiness.com. The U.S. Tennis Association says it intends to hold the U.S. open in New York started in August without fans, if it gets government support.

The Denver Broncos signed a deal with FanDuel to become the first NFL team to partner with a sports book and finally this Burger King launches an impossible sausage breakfast sandwich. Maria, if I was with you in the same studio, I'd bring you one but alas, we are socially distanced. So we can just think about it together.

BARTIROMO: See, another impact of this pandemic and shut down. There you go. There's that too, Cheryl. Thank you.

CASONE: you bet.

BARTIROMO: We got a market rallying this morning. Futures indicating a triple digit move right out of the gate. Dow industrials up 437 points right now on reports that the Trump administration is considering more stimulus, this time a $1 trillion infrastructure package. Most of the money set aside for traditional projects like roads and bridges but there could be fun for 5G wireless infrastructure and rural broadband as well, we understand.

Joining me right now over the phone is Cornerstone Macros Co-founder and Chief Economist Nancy Lazar. Nancy, it is always a pleasure to talk to you. Thanks very much for joining me and I am looking at your most recent report, talking about some of the flattening of the curve and the flattening of the spread.

Are you not worried that as the economy reopens then we are or could be seeing spikes in certain corners of the country and these worries over a second wave of this disease, Nancy?

NANCY LAZAR, CO-FOUNDER, CORNERSTONE MACROS & CHIEF ECONOMIST (on the phone): Well, there's no question you need to be worried about it but I still think you're going to get an economic recovery because there has been so much support from the federal government and indeed you're opening up the economy.

So I'm calling it a wavy recovery but I think it is going to be a recovery none the less and I do think we're getting a big rebound in a lot of the economic data.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we were just talking about the second quarter and one of our guests were looking for a contraction of 28 percent in the second quarter. How do you see it in terms of growth, this year Nancy?

Do you think that that is going to be the most sizable contraction second quarter but then we see growth in the second half of the year as the administration seems to believe?

LAZAR: I do. I think this is probably going to be the shortest recession on record and I have also GDP data of 25 percent for the - for the second quarter but as you know, the May data have already turned over and we're going to get more of that data this morning at 8:30, with retail - with retail sales.

So yes, 2Q is going to be massively negative but I think that's old news. The new news is we're seeing this big rebound in economic data which to be sure, will slow down as we go into the back half of the year, potentially become a second - a second wave but none the less recovery and a sustainable recovery here and around - around the world.

BARTIROMO: What about the Federal Reserve and what we're going today and tomorrow from J. Powell. He's delivering his semi-annual policy report to Congress. The Central Bank said to begin using its new secondary market corporate credit facility to buy individual corporate bonds from eligible issuers. The Fed opened at $600 billion mainstreet lending program on Monday.

That's benefiting small and midsize businesses, Nancy. Do you think these new facilities are going to keep the economy get it as you say growing in the second half? Give us your take on what we might hear from J. Powell today.

LAZAR: I think it's perfectly clear, don't fight the Fed. I know that's a bad, an old cliche but I think it is very, very true from the Fed to the BOJ to the ECB, policy makers around the world arms are going to make sure to increase the odds that indeed this recovery can continue.

And the reason that I'm - I'm potentially more confident than - than some is because I've already seen signs that all this stimulus in which they are - they are doing more and I think that will be the message today. They will do whatever it takes to strive you said years ago.

You're already seen evidence that the stimulus is working, you've got a very clear rebound in house, very strong rebound in housing unfolding. We haven't seen that early pick up in housing in 20 years. That is the last - the last expansion, housing did not rebound for obvious reasons.

You were unwinding - unwinding the bubble so housing rebounding early in expansion is a classic sign that policy is working. Consumers are confident and obviously investing in a large - in a large ticket item so yes, policy is already working. They're going to continue to do more, not only here but around the world.

And that's important that we're seeing global stimulus because we're not the loan you know man in a forest. We've got a lot of support from policy makers around the world, increasing the odds that this is a synchronized global recovery, not just the recovery here in the United States.

BARTIROMO: Yes, really fascinating stuff that the Federal Reserve is going to be buying bonds from companies like Microsoft, Apple and yet you hear what J. Powell said last week that some companies, some people will not be able to go back to the jobs that they had, that this is going to be a long recovery.

Nancy, what are you telling clients in terms of allocating capital in an environment where there is this kind of uncertainty and a sizeable amount of debt once we get out of this?

LAZAR: So first, I don't mean to downplay at all what's going on with Covid, it's a unique crisis to be sure but coming out of every recession, there is always a part of the economy that struggles. We all remember the housing about when housing was not a part of the last expansion.

If you look historically, manufacturing from 2002 to 2007 during that expansion, manufacturing jobs declined by two million so I'll stop but I can go back historically. There is always a headwind coming out of recession. This is a unique head wind and that it wasn't caused and that you didn't have a particular bubble bursting in this recession.

But there is a consequence of the leisure industry being a headwind to employment going forward. The last 2010-2019 expansion, employment did not hit a new high for four years from its trough and quite frankly, and that was in part because of the headwinds from housing and that's probably going to be the same thing today.

Quite frankly, I had forgotten that employment was so weak for so long in the last expansion because by the back half of the expansion, obviously things were pretty - were pretty robust. So yes, there's going to be an adjustment coming out of this crisis. The key is that the Federal Reserve is encouraging companies to potentially reinvest in this country of two special support for capital spending in this country.

One, corporate bond yields prior to the Fed moves yesterday were already down over 150 basis points. They're going to be down even more given what the Fed announced yesterday. That's important for capital spending and then back and obviously the on-shoring theme is also important for capital spending.

So my point is there will be new drivers of growth, I think one will be manufacturing in part because of the capital spending is likely to happen for many, many reasons and - and to be sure this onshoring theme is one of them because that's how you actually create new jobs.

So I'm trying to look through and - and it's not again, downplay the Covid crisis but look through it, look longer term. Are there longer term growth drivers in this country and the answer is yes. Capital spending, manufacturing are going to create jobs and as well as housing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think you make so many important points especially since we know that Peter Navarro is the point man on trying to work on getting manufacturing supply chains from China, out of China and in the United States or elsewhere.

We're going to need that manufacturing base to get fired up again, Nancy. We love hearing from you this morning. Thank you so much. We'll be watching your research certainly. Nancy Lazar joining us from Cornerstone Macros. Thank you Nancy. Have a good day. Coming up, the U.S. jobs market attempting to recover. We're taking a look at how radiology is an emerging and up and coming industry for American jobs, post pandemic.

That's coming up and then so long standardized testing. Bye - bye. Another major university joins the long list of colleges not requiring the ACT and SAT exams. We'll tell you which one. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The next jobs in America. The coronavirus pandemic creating an enhanced focus on medicine and prevention and a huge amount of job opportunities in radiology. The specialty is one of the vital services used to help diagnose the most severe cases of Covid-19.

Joining me right now is Zwagner-Pesiri Radiology, Chief Operating Officer and licensed to X-ray, MRI and CT technologist, Robert Day. Robert, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks very much for joining us. Tell us about radiology jobs. What types of jobs will be in the most demand?

Sure, good morning. So it was actually a boon for us during the pandemic. One of the things at the very beginning on the onset of the pandemic, when testing was at a premium. One of the things that we saw personally here at the practice was that chest X-rays were actually what we were using to help diagnose positive cases of Covid.

It became very important to kind of help direct the patients that were having trouble getting into the hospital or having trouble becoming - being tested, we were using chest X-rays, the most basic form of what we do.

I mean, radiology is you know, been around forever. It's a growing field as the modalities kind of develop and the technology advances but right now X- ray is something that's blooming in the medical field.

BARTIROMO: So I mean you know just about a year ago, I was on doing a special on AI and everything I did on AI on radiology pointed to radiology jobs are going to get targeted by AI, that Artificial Intelligence can understand how to operate radiology machines and that people would be out of work and now all of a sudden we're seeing job opportunities in radiology.

What about technology and AI replacing those jobs? Is this a short term boost in job opportunities in radiology or do you see this longer lasting?

DAY: I see it as something that you know believe it or not, AI's been part of part of the field for a while. AI is something that we use to enhance and streamline workflows but at the end of the day, radiology is a very hands-on, patient-orientated, clinical you know, job where you still, even with AI helping us do our jobs, making this more efficient, we still need technologist to you know, talk to and put the patients on the table, understand why we're doing a study and you know the AI is going to help us and enhance what we're doing.

But it will be a long, long road to actually replace the technologist.

BARTIROMO: So real good before you go, real quick before you go Robert, what are the skillsets and training that one needs to get to get a job in radiology?

DAY: Yes, it's you know kind of the sweet spot because you know, I always explain to people, it's kind of almost like doing an apprenticeship so you do need a 2-year Associate's degree to become a licensed X-ray, tech CT, MRI, nuclear medicine or sonography. It's a 2-year degree that's required.

But a lot of the training is not so much didactic. It's more of a hands-on, clinical training so it's kind of like an apprenticeship. It's kind of like learning how to become an electrician. Most of the training is actually done, doing the procedure so it's a - part of it's you know, that that skill of education where you going to need to go and learn some anatomy and physiology and physics.

But most of the training, the really intense training, what will make you a proficient and a highly skilled technologist is actually hands-on, doing the job.

BARTIROMO: OK, we will leave it there. Robert, it's great to get your insights on this. Thanks so much. Robert Day joining us there on opportunities in radiology. Still ahead so long standardized testing. Another major university joining the long list of colleges not requiring the ACT or SAT exams. We'll say which ones right after this. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Time for the morning buzz. First up, Harvard University dropping standardized test requirements for 2021. Applicants will not have to submit ACT or SAT scores due to the coronavirus disruptions, Cabot, your reaction.

CABOT PHILIPS, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, CAMPUSREFORM.ORG: Well, this is nothing to do with coronavirus. They're trying to make it sound like well, the SAT tests have been disrupted around the country. That's why we're doing this but this has a lot more to do with them wanting to take away this requirement. We covered the campus reform, how Harvard faced a big lawsuit earlier in the year because they were discriminating its Asian students.

The average Asian student has a score 220 points on average, higher than the average student of other races. They faced that lawsuit, it's bad publicity for them and so they're trying to remove anything that's politically incorrect.

And in this case they say and they feel in many ways that the SAT test can be discriminatory to students of different backgrounds even though I think a lot of people look at the SAT tests as a perfect barometer where all other things are taken into account and it's a way to grade students based on their ability.

So this is happening around the country. I think a lot of other schools are going to be following suit now that Harvard has set the precedent because you know, universities are facing kind of a politically incorrect you know, accusations because they put so much weight on the SAT.

So this is going to be the new growing trend in academia.

BARTIROMO: Wow, really interesting actually and then next, United Airlines doubles down on its flyers. United now making wearing a mask mandatory to fly as of Thursday. Passengers not comply will be denied boarding and placed on an internal travel restriction list. Dagen, what do you think?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: How far are they going to go in policing this because I'd say a solid one third of the people I see walking around New York City wearing masks have them below their nose, is that really the way to wear it?

So now the job of the flight attendant will not only to be to make sure people have masks on, to make sure that they are positioned properly. Come on.

BARTIROMO: Jon, what do you think?

JON HILSENRATH, SENIOR WRITER, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: You know, I'm interested in that - interested in that Harvard case. I mean, there's been a lot of debate over the years about the SAT and ACT and whether they're discriminatory by race or income level. There's a lawsuit in California over this.

So to a certain extent yes, this - I think this is going to be a test case of whether schools can you know process all these applications without depending too much on SAT and ACT.

BARTIROMO: How about this? Tom Brady's new look, we're going to see it. The Tampa Bay Buccaneers asking fans over social media when the team should release photos of Brady in his new uniform. Brady responding, simply saying, tomorrow. What do you think about that, Jon?

HILSENRATH: I'm a Giants' fan, you know. Good luck Tom Brady down in Florida, in Florida. I hope I never have to deal with you again.

BARTIROMO: Oh God. Dagen, you want to see his new uniform?

MCDOWELL: Sure. If - I think it's probably makes more palatable shirtless.

BARTIROMO: A vision to go to commercial break on. Thank you everybody. We'll be right back. Stay with us.
